objnote.p: Regarding distribution, Bentley notes that this prospectus was most likely sent by Blake to his friends in May 1809 (*Writings* volume 2, page 1692). J.B. Mertz identified a previously unrecorded copy found pasted alongside another prospectus for a print by Robert Hartley Cromek in Francis Douce's edition of Chaucer. This copy is now held at the Bodleian Library as part of Douce's estate (Mertz, "An Unrecorded Copy of Blake's 1809 Chaucer Prospectus," *Blake/An Illustrated Quarterly* 32.3 (Winter:1998-99), page 74).

objinfo.note: Printed on one side of a leaf of broadsheet with the verso left blank.
According to materials from the British Museum, this prospectus is bound with Copy A of the other prospectus for the Chaucer engraving (BB11) in a card cover.

provenance.name: British Museum
provenance.note: Probably acquired by Anne (Mrs. Alexander) Gilchrist at an unknown time; likely bequeath by inheritance in 1885 to her son, Herbert H. Gilchrist; sold by H. H. Gilchrist with thirteen other works by Blake and his brother Robert, including Robert Blake's drawing of the *Approach of Doom*, to the British Museum for £150 in June 1894.

THE CANTERBURY PILGRIMS.

l.note: In the printed text, this is a decorative line.

lg.l: THE FRESCO PICTURE,
Representing CHAUCER'S Characters, painted by
WILLIAM BLAKE,

l.hi: As it is now submitted to the Public,

lg.l: THE Designer proposes to Engrave, in a correct and finished Line manner of

Engraving, similar to those original Copper Plates of
ALBERT Albrecht
DURERDürerDuerer,
LUCASLucas van LeydenLucas HugenszLucas Jacobsz,
HISBENHans Sebald Beham,

ALDEGRAVE Heinrich Aldegrever Heinrich Aldegraf
and the old original Engravers, who were great Masters in Painting and
Designing, whose method, alone, can delineate Character as it is in this Picture,
where all the Lineaments are distinct.
It is hoped that the Painter will be allowed by the Public (notwithstanding artfully

dissemminated diseminated
Bentley notes that the 1809 version uses 'dissemminated' instead of 'disseminated' (*Writings* volume 2, page 824). insinuations to the contrary) to be better able than any other to keep
his own Characters and Expressions; having had sufficient evidence in the Works of

our own
HOGARTHWilliam Hogarth, that no other Artist can reach the original Spirit so well as the
Painter himself, especially as Mr. B. is an old well-known and acknowledged Engraver.
The size of the Engraving will be 3-feet 1-inch long, by 1-foot high.—The Artist
engages to deliver it, finished, in One Year from September next.—Bentley notes that the date is Oct. 8, 1810 (*Writings* volume 2, page 824).No Work of Art,
can take longer than a Year: it may be worked backwards and forwards without end,
and last a Man's whole Life; but he will, at length, only be forced to bring it back to
what it was, and it will be worse than it was at the end of the first Twelve Months.
The Value of this Artist's Year is the Criterion of Society: and as it is valued, so does
Society flourish or decay.
The Price to Subscribers—FOUR GUINEAS, Bentely notes that the new price in 1810 was three guineas (*Writings* volume 2, page 824). Two to be paid at the time of
Subscribing, the other Two, on delivery of the Print.
Subscriptions received at No. 28, Corner of BROAD-STREET, GOLDEN-SQUARE;
where the Picture is now Exhibiting, among other Works, by the same Artist.
The Price will be considerably raised to Non-subscribers.
